title: Can you still feel a limb that's gone? - Joshua W. Pate

multiple-choice.question: What is a common experience for people who have lost a limb?

options.label: A
options.text: They can no longer feel their phantom limb.

options.label: B
options.text: They can feel their phantom limb, but it's only a memory.

options.label: C
options.text: They can feel their phantom limb in complete lifelike detail.

options.label: D
options.text: They can only see their phantom limb.

multiple-choice.question: What is the likely cause of phantom limb sensations?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of sensory neurons in the limb.

options.label: B
options.text: The absence of sensory neurons in the limb.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain's map of the body.

options.label: D
options.text: The body's response to injury.

options.label: A
options.text: They are not painful.

options.label: B
options.text: They are only visible.

options.label: C
options.text: They are painful.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not felt.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Brain Body Map

options.label: D
options.text: Sensory Cortex Model

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Medications for pain management

options.label: D
options.text: Prosthetics

options.label: C

title: The "End Of History" Illusion - Bence Nanay

multiple-choice.question: According to recent research, what is the name of the phenomenon where people fail to predict change in themselves?

options.label: A
options.text: The End of History Illusion

options.label: B
options.text: The Future Uncertainty Principle

options.label: C
options.text: The Change Resistance Theory

options.label: D
options.text: The Predictive Paradox

multiple-choice.question: What was the main finding of the 2013 paper "The End of History Illusion"?

options.label: A
options.text: People tend to overestimate their capacity for change.

options.label: B
options.text: People tend to underestimate their capacity for change.

options.label: C
options.text: People tend to predict more change in themselves than they actually experience.

options.label: D
options.text: People tend to experience more change in themselves than they predict.

multiple-choice.question: What is one consequence of the end of history illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: People are less likely to make long-term plans.

options.label: B
options.text: People are more likely to overinvest in future choices based on present preferences.

options.label: C
options.text: People are less likely to change their preferences over time.

options.label: D
options.text: People are more likely to predict more change in themselves than they actually experience.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the name of the political scientist who predicted that liberal democracy was the final form of government?

options.label: A
options.text: Francis Fukuyama

options.label: B
options.text: Karl Marx

options.label: C
options.text: John Locke

options.label: D
options.text: Adam Smith

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that the end of history illusion applies to our individual lives, but also to the wider world?

options.label: A
options.text: We are unable to predict change in ourselves, but we are able to predict change in the world.

options.label: B
options.text: We are unable to predict change in ourselves, but we are able to predict change in the world.

options.label: C
options.text: We are unable to predict change in ourselves, and we are also unable to predict change in the world.

options.label: D
options.text: We are able to predict change in ourselves, and we are also able to predict change in the world.

title: Why should you read Edgar Allan Poe? - Scott Peeples

multiple-choice.question: What are two cardinal rules that Edgar Allan Poe identified for the short story form?

options.label: A
options.text: It must be long enough to read in one sitting, and every word must contribute to its purpose.

options.label: B
options.text: It must be short enough to read in one sitting, and every word must contribute to its purpose.

options.label: C
options.text: It must be written in verse, and every word must contribute to its purpose.

options.label: D
options.text: It must be a novel, and every word must contribute to its purpose.

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of Poe's stories that makes them unique?

options.label: A
options.text: They often have clear moral messages.

options.label: B
options.text: They often have simple interpretations.

options.label: C
options.text: They use violence and horror to explore the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt.

options.label: D
options.text: They often have supernatural elements.

multiple-choice.question: What literary device does Poe use in his stories to engage readers and make them active participants?

options.label: A
options.text: Unreliable narrators

options.label: B
options.text: Unreliable characters

options.label: C
options.text: Unreliable plot twists

options.label: D
options.text: Unreliable dialogue

multiple-choice.question: What is a notable contribution of Poe to the literary world?

options.label: A
options.text: He invented the science fiction genre.

options.label: B
options.text: He invented the detective story as we know it.

options.label: C
options.text: He invented the adventure novel.

options.label: D
options.text: He invented the satirical essay.

multiple-choice.question: What is a notable aspect of Poe's personal life?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a successful financially throughout his career.

options.label: B
options.text: He had a happy and stable family life.

options.label: C
options.text: He struggled with alcoholism and frequently antagonized other popular writers.

options.label: D
options.text: He had no close friends or acquaintances.

options.text: 100 years

options.label: C
options.text: 200 winters

options.label: B
options.text: It would remain the same as it is now.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: 35,000 years

options.label: C

title: How do cigarettes affect the body? - Krishna Sudhir

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the teeth and gums as a result of smoking?

options.label: A
options.text: They become stronger and more resistant to decay.

options.label: B
options.text: They are damaged by the tar in cigarette smoke, leading to tooth decay.

options.label: C
options.text: They are completely unaffected by smoking.

options.label: D
options.text: They begin to grow back after quitting.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the immediate physical benefits of quitting smoking?

options.label: A
options.text: The risk of heart disease increases by 50%.

options.label: B
options.text: The heart rate and blood pressure return to normal within 20 minutes.

options.label: C
options.text: The lungs become healthier and less prone to infection within a day.

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of stroke decreases by 10%.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of nicotine in the brain when a smoker inhales cigarette smoke?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes a decrease in dopamine and other neurotransmitters.

options.label: B
options.text: It triggers the release of dopamine and other neurotransmitters, making smoking highly addictive.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: It increases the risk of cancer.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the long-term physical benefits of quitting smoking?

options.label: A
options.text: The risk of heart disease increases by 50% after 5 years.

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of stroke continues to reduce after 5 years.

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of fatal lung cancer goes down by 50% after 10 years.

options.label: D
options.text: The likelihood of developing coronary heart disease is the same as that of a non-smoker after 15 years.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the tools that can help smokers stay cigarette-free?

options.label: A
options.text: Only nicotine replacement therapy.

options.label: B
options.text: Only counselling and support groups.

options.label: C
options.text: Nicotine replacement therapy, counselling and support groups, cognitive behavioral therapy, and moderate intensity exercise.

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above.

options.text: It depends on the individual's interpretation.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Compression

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: According to researchers, what is one reason why certain expressions are universal?

options.label: C
options.text: They are learned behaviors that vary across cultures.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a result of cultural conditioning.

options.label: A
options.text: They are a result of cultural conditioning.

options.label: B
options.text: They are important for social status.

options.label: C
options.text: They are linked to our physiology, such as improving survival in potentially dangerous situations.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a result of learned behaviors.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one way that emotional expressions can be similar across cultures?

options.text: A major heart attack.

multiple-choice.question: What are the three rules that the chemistry teacher established for his lesson planning after his experience?

options.label: A
options.text: Rule number one: Be confident in your teaching methods.

options.label: B
options.text: Rule number one: Curiosity comes first, questions can be windows to great instruction.

options.label: C
options.text: Rule number one: Technology is the key to effective teaching.

options.label: D
options.text: Rule number one: Follow the scripted curriculum at all costs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge that the chemistry teacher sees for Riley's future teachers?

options.label: A
options.text: How to make the curriculum more engaging for Riley.

options.label: B
options.text: How to grow Riley's curiosity and inquiry.

options.label: C
options.text: How to make the classroom more comfortable for Riley.

options.label: D
options.text: How to deal with Riley's constant questioning.

multiple-choice.question: What is the chemistry teacher's main message to educators?

options.label: A
options.text: To leave behind their role as disseminators of content and become more like scripted curriculum.

options.label: B
options.text: To focus on the technology aspect of education.

options.label: C
options.text: To cultivate curiosity and inquiry in their students and bring meaning to their school day.

options.label: D
options.text: To prioritize the teacher's own comfort and ease in the classroom.

title: How one scientist averted a national health crisis - Andrea Tone

multiple-choice.question: What was Frances Oldham Kelsey's role at the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) when she was assigned to review the application for the drug thalidomide?

options.label: A
options.text: Director of the FDA

options.label: B
options.text: Senior Scientist

options.label: C
options.text: Newest recruit

options.label: D
options.text: FDA Colleague

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for Frances Kelsey's initial rejection of Merrell's application for thalidomide?

options.label: A
options.text: The drug's lack of effectiveness

options.label: B
options.text: The company's failure to test the drug on pregnant animals

options.label: C
options.text: The FDA's classification of thalidomide as a controlled substance

options.label: D
options.text: The drug's potential for addiction

multiple-choice.question: What were the consequences of thalidomide's widespread use during pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: Mild side effects, such as headaches and nausea

options.label: B
options.text: Severe birth defects, including extra appendages, shorter limbs, or no limbs at all

options.label: C
options.text: Increased risk of miscarriage

options.label: D
options.text: No significant health effects

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Frances Kelsey's efforts to have thalidomide approved in the US?

options.label: A
options.text: The FDA approved thalidomide for use in the US

options.label: B
options.text: The FDA rejected thalidomide's application multiple times

options.label: C
options.text: Merrell withdrew thalidomide from the US market voluntarily

options.label: D
options.text: The US government imposed a ban on thalidomide

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the thalidomide tragedy, as it relates to the FDA's authority and requirements for new drug applications?

options.label: A
options.text: The FDA's authority was reduced, and requirements for new drug applications were relaxed

options.label: B
options.text: The FDA's authority was expanded, and requirements for new drug applications were toughened

options.label: C
options.text: The FDA's authority remained unchanged, and requirements for new drug applications remained the same

options.label: D
options.text: The FDA was abolished, and a new agency was created to regulate drugs

title: What would it be like to live on the moon? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the main obstacle to living on the moon?

options.label: A
options.text: Cold weather

options.label: B
options.text: Lack of atmosphere and magnetic field

options.label: C
options.text: Limited access to water and food

options.label: D
options.text: High gravity

multiple-choice.question: What would be a likely first step in establishing a moon camp?

options.label: A
options.text: Constructing habitats from lunar soil

options.label: B
options.text: Transporting supplies from Earth

options.label: C
options.text: Building shelters inside caves formed by lava tubes

options.label: D
options.text: Establishing a water treatment plant

multiple-choice.question: Why would lunar inhabitants need to exercise for hours a day?

options.label: A
options.text: To maintain bone and muscle mass due to low gravity

options.label: B
options.text: To build up strength for spacewalks

options.label: C
options.text: To recover from the effects of cosmic radiation

options.label: D
options.text: To stay awake during long periods of isolation

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential benefit of a moon base beyond the moon itself?

options.label: A
options.text: Access to new resources and minerals

options.label: B
options.text: Increased understanding of the moon's geology

options.label: C
options.text: A testing ground for future space operations and a refueling station

options.label: D
options.text: A place for humans to escape the Earth's atmosphere

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential economic benefit of a moon base?

options.label: A
options.text: Access to new markets and trade opportunities

options.label: B
options.text: Increased understanding of the moon's geology

options.label: C
options.text: A source of new minerals and resources, such as silicon, aluminum, and magnesium

options.label: D
options.text: A place for humans to mine for rare earth elements

title: Can you solve the penniless pilgrim riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: How many blocks does the town of Duonia consist of?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 blocks

options.label: B
options.text: 15 blocks

options.label: C
options.text: 16 blocks

options.label: D
options.text: 20 blocks

multiple-choice.question: What is the unique tax imposed on all visitors in Duonia?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases by one silver for every block walked east and doubles for every block walked south.

options.label: B
options.text: It increases by two silver for every block walked east and doubles for every block walked south.

options.label: C
options.text: It increases by two silver for every block walked east and halves for every block walked south.

options.label: D
options.text: It increases by two silver for every block walked east and subtracts two silver for every block walked south.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to your tax bill when you walk clockwise starting from east?

options.label: A
options.text: Your tax bill decreases by one silver.

options.label: B
options.text: Your tax bill increases by one silver.

options.label: C
options.text: Your tax bill remains the same.

options.label: D
options.text: Your tax bill becomes one smaller than it started.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to reducing your tax bill in Duonia?

options.label: A
options.text: Walking the same block twice.

options.label: B
options.text: Walking a large counterclockwise loop through the city.

options.label: C
options.text: Walking a large clockwise loop through the city.

options.label: D
options.text: Walking north and then west.

multiple-choice.question: What is the final amount of tax you owe after walking through the city?

options.label: A
options.text: 0 silver

options.label: B
options.text: 1 silver

options.label: C
options.text: -1 silver

options.label: D
options.text: 8 silver

title: Why is it so hard to cure ALS? - Fernando Vieira

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the rare neuromuscular disorder that Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with in 1963?

options.label: A
options.text: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)

options.label: B
options.text: Motor neuron disease

options.label: C
options.text: Lou Gehrig’s Disease

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of ALS cases are hereditary, where a mother or father with ALS passes on a mutated gene to their child?
What is the typical lifespan of a person with ALS after diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: 1-2 years

options.label: B
options.text: 2-5 years

options.label: C
options.text: 5-10 years

options.label: D
options.text: 10-20 years

multiple-choice.question: What is the prevailing mystery of ALS?

options.label: A
options.text: The cause of motor neuron degeneration

options.label: B
options.text: The role of genetic mutations

options.label: C
options.text: The impact of environmental factors

options.label: D
options.text: The effect of toxins on motor neurons

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the new avenues of treatment being developed for ALS?

options.label: A
options.text: Gene therapy to slow the advancement of the disease

options.label: B
options.text: Stem cell therapy to repair damaged cells

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

title: The journey to Pluto, the farthest world ever explored - Alan Stern

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary objective of the New Horizons mission?

options.label: A
options.text: To explore the Kuiper Belt and collect scientific data

options.label: B
options.text: To study the effects of gravity on celestial bodies

options.label: C
options.text: To test the reliability of the spacecraft's instruments

options.label: D
options.text: To conduct a flyby of Pluto and gather data on its atmosphere

multiple-choice.question: Why did the New Horizons spacecraft need to reach Pluto as fast as possible?

options.label: A
options.text: To avoid the harsh conditions of space

options.label: B
options.text: To take advantage of a rare astronomical event

options.label: C
options.text: To reach Pluto before its atmosphere froze

options.label: D
options.text: To test the spacecraft's speed limits

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the gravity assist that New Horizons received from Jupiter?

options.label: A
options.text: It provided additional power to the spacecraft

options.label: B
options.text: It increased the spacecraft's speed to 50,000 kilometers per hour

options.label: C
options.text: It allowed the spacecraft to change direction and head towards Pluto

options.label: D
options.text: It enabled the spacecraft to collect data on Jupiter's atmosphere

multiple-choice.question: Why was the New Horizons spacecraft unable to slow down and enter orbit around Pluto?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was too far away from Earth

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was traveling too fast

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was designed for a flyby mission

options.label: D
options.text: Because it lacked the necessary fuel

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the mission control team's efforts to reload the core load into New Horizons?

options.label: A
options.text: They were unable to reload the core load, and the mission was a failure

options.label: B
options.text: They successfully reloaded the core load, but it was too late to recover the lost data

options.label: C
options.text: They successfully reloaded the core load, and New Horizons was able to take and broadcast breathtaking images of Pluto

options.label: D
options.text: They were unable to contact New Horizons, and the mission was abandoned

title: Why do we sweat? - John Murnan

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of sweating during exercise?

options.label: A
options.text: To cool the body through evaporation

options.label: B
options.text: To provide energy for the muscles

options.label: C
options.text: To stimulate muscle activity

options.label: D
options.text: To widen blood vessels

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the hypothalamus in regulating body temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase muscle activity

options.label: B
options.text: To stimulate sweat glands

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate body temperature by sending signals to the sweat glands

options.label: D
options.text: To widen blood vessels

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which water moves into the sweat gland?

options.label: A
options.text: Osmosis

options.label: B
options.text: Diffusion

options.label: C
options.text: Active transport

options.label: D
options.text: Passive transport

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the cells lining the sweat gland duct?

options.label: A
options.text: To reclaim salt from the primary secretion

options.label: B
options.text: To produce more sweat

options.label: C
options.text: To widen blood vessels

options.label: D
options.text: To stimulate muscle activity

multiple-choice.question: Why do people sweat when they eat spicy food?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the spices trigger the fight or flight response

options.label: B
options.text: Because the spices stimulate the hypothalamus to increase muscle activity

options.label: C
options.text: Because the spices trigger the same neural response in the brain that activates temperature receptors

options.label: D
options.text: Because the spices widen blood vessels

title: How does hibernation work? - Sheena Faherty

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why animals hibernate?

options.label: A
options.text: To conserve energy and survive the harsh winter months.

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate their body temperature and stay warm.

options.label: C
options.text: To socialize and interact with other animals.

options.label: D
options.text: To adapt to their environment and find food.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following animals is known to give birth and lactate while hibernating?

options.label: A
options.text: Arctic ground squirrel

options.label: B
options.text: Fat-tailed dwarf lemur

options.label: C
options.text: Female black bear

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the phenomenon where hibernating animals experience regular bouts of reduced metabolic rate and body temperature, followed by normal metabolic rate and body temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: Hibernation cycle

options.label: B
options.text: Torpor

options.label: C
options.text: Interbout arousal

options.label: D
options.text: Metabolic shift

multiple-choice.question: What have researchers discovered is controlling hibernation in animals?

options.label: A
options.text: A specific hormone

options.label: B
options.text: A unique gene

options.label: C
options.text: Genes that turn off and on in unique patterns throughout the year

options.label: D
options.text: A complex neural network

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential benefit of studying hibernation in animals?

options.label: A
options.text: Understanding how to improve athletic performance

options.label: B
options.text: Developing new methods for space travel

options.label: C
options.text: Discovering how to protect the brain during a stroke

options.label: D
options.text: D: Understanding how to control weight gain in humans

title: How do we study living brains? - John Borghi and Elizabeth Waters

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in studying the human brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Its complexity and interconnectedness

options.label: B
options.text: Its ability to adapt to new situations

options.label: C
options.text: Its inability to communicate with other brains

options.label: D
options.text: Its lack of electrical activity

multiple-choice.question: Which technique measures electrical activity in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: fMRI

options.label: B
options.text: PET

options.label: C
options.text: EEG

options.label: D
options.text: MRI

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of EEG in determining the location of brain activity?

options.label: A
options.text: Its inability to measure oxygen consumption

options.label: B
options.text: Its inability to pinpoint differences in brain activity

options.label: C
options.text: Its difficulty in isolating the source of electrical signals

options.label: D
options.text: Its high cost

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of using fMRI in brain imaging?

options.label: A
options.text: Its high speed and low cost

options.label: B
options.text: Its ability to pinpoint differences in brain activity to within a few millimeters

options.label: C
options.text: Its ability to measure oxygen consumption in the brain

options.label: D
options.text: Its ability to detect diseases like Alzheimer's

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of PET scans in brain imaging?

options.label: A
options.text: Its high cost and low speed

options.label: B
options.text: Its inability to measure electrical activity in the brain

options.label: C
options.text: Its low time resolution and need for radioactive material

options.label: D
options.text: Its inability to detect diseases like Alzheimer's
